title: Don't Look Now
descriptions:
Don’t Look Now (1973) is a psychological horror-thriller about grief, perception, and fate. After their young daughter Christine drowns near their English countryside home, married couple John and Laura Baxter travel to Venice, where John has taken a church restoration job in hopes of healing their loss. Venice, off-season and labyrinthine, becomes a damp, decaying maze that mirrors their disorientation and sorrow.

While dining, Laura meets two elderly sisters, one of whom, Heather, claims to be a blind psychic who can see Christine’s spirit and insists the child is happy. Heather warns that John is in danger if he remains in Venice. Laura is comforted, briefly buoyed by the idea their daughter persists beyond death, and her faith is rekindled. John, a rationalist, dismisses the supernatural and bristles at Heather’s influence. Their marriage, strained by trauma, oscillates between moments of intimacy and distance—most notably in a famous intercut sequence that juxtaposes lovemaking with the couple dressing afterward, underscoring their attempts at reconnection.

Meanwhile, Venice is plagued by reports of a serial killer. John experiences unsettling visions: fleeting glimpses of a small figure in a red coat—like the one Christine wore when she died—darting through alleys and across bridges. He also sees strange portents, including a falling scaffolding incident that nearly kills him, and a spectral image in a church slide that seems to predict disaster. Laura, convinced by Heather’s warnings, plans to leave Venice. John believes he sees Laura on a funeral barge with the sisters, presuming she’s fallen into a morbid delusion or that something sinister is afoot. He contacts the police, who detain the sisters and fuel an atmosphere of suspicion, but Laura later reappears, very much alive, and urges John to let go and depart.

John continues to pursue the red-coated figure, compulsively drawn by the hope it might be Christine or a sign meant for him. He follows the apparition into the city’s darkest corners—echoing the theme of not recognizing the signs in front of us. Ultimately, he corners the figure in a dilapidated building, only to discover it is not a child at all but a small, malevolent killer who turns and slashes his throat. As he dies, John experiences a cascade of images and realizes the visions he dismissed were warnings of his own impending death. The sisters’ prophecy is fulfilled: he should not have stayed in Venice.

In the aftermath, Laura rides on the funeral barge, mourning, accompanied by the sisters, the city’s canals now funereal and still. The film leaves the couple’s love and grief suspended in a tragic, fatal loop, suggesting that seeing is not always understanding, and that denial can lead us to enact the very fate we fear. Don’t Look Now weaves loss, psychic suggestion, and the city’s oppressive atmosphere into a haunting meditation on how memory and foreboding can betray the senses.
